title: How to Set a Pocket Watch (Pendant, Lever, Key, Pin & More)

steps.title: Pull on the crown of the watch to see if it is pendant-set.
steps.content: Pull on the crown of the watch to see if it is pendant-set. The crown is a rotating button at the top of the watch above the number 12. Unlike other watches, the crown on a pendant-set watch will press in and pull out. If the crown moves up and down, it is a pendant-set watch. [1] X Research source Use gentle force to pull up on the crown. A pendant set watch should move fairly easily from 1 setting to another. If you have a rotating crown and there is no lever or pin button, you can assume you have a pendant watch. This is the most common setting in modern pocket watches.

steps.title: Look for a lever to identify a lever-set watch.
steps.content: Look for a lever to identify a lever-set watch. Look for a small metal tab sticking out from under the dial. This may be hidden under the case over the dial, so you may need to remove the front case to find the lever. A lever-set watch will also have a rotating crown. [2] X Research source Lever-set watches are also known as railroad watches. They are more common in antique watches, but they may also appear in some modern watches.

steps.title: Identify a key-set watch by the lack of a rotating crown.
steps.content: Identify a key-set watch by the lack of a rotating crown. The easiest way to tell a key-set watch is to try to turn the crown at the top of the watch. If it won’t turn, you have a key-set watch. Furthermore, if your watch comes with a key, you can assume it is a key-set watch. [3] X Research source While modern watches may have a key, key setting is the oldest form of pocket watch. If your watch comes from before the late 19th century, you most likely have a key-set watch.

steps.title: Check for a small button near the crown to see if it is pin-set.
steps.content: Check for a small button near the crown to see if it is pin-set. This button may be very small, but it will be raised up from the rest of the watch. A pin-set watch will also have a rotating crown at the top of the watch. [4] X Research source Pin-setting is more common in European watches than American, and it is not very common in higher end watches.

steps.title: Pull the crown up to activate the setting mechanism.
steps.content: Pull the crown up to activate the setting mechanism. There may be a snap or a click when you pull the crown up. If the crown won’t hold in this position or if the crown is stuck, take it into a watch maker or repairman. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Turn the crown to set the time.
steps.content: Turn the crown to set the time. Turn the crown clockwise to move the hands clockwise. Turn the crown counterclockwise to move the hands in the opposite direction. Once you have reached the right time, stop turning the crown. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Press the crown back into the watch.
steps.content: Press the crown back into the watch. The crown should now be in the middle position. Do not push it all the way in unless you want to wind your watch. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Push the crown down to wind the watch if needed.
steps.content: Push the crown down to wind the watch if needed. Pushing the crown in will activate the winding mechanism. Once the crown is pushed in, rotate the crown clockwise until it won't turn anymore. When you are done, pull the crown back up to the middle position. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Locate the lever on the face of the pocket watch.
steps.content: Locate the lever on the face of the pocket watch. Where the lever is located may vary. Often, it will be hidden under the bezel and crystal (which is the glass case over the dial). Open the bezel and crystal by screwing off the lid, snapping it off, or prying it open with a finger nail. [9] X Research source The lever will look like a small piece of metal with a raised lip. Most of it will be hiding under the watch face.

steps.title: Pull the lever out with your fingernail.
steps.content: Pull the lever out with your fingernail. Use gentle pressure to pull the lever out from under the dial. The lever should easily spring out towards you. This will activate the setting mechanism. If the lever is stuck, don’t force it. Contact the manufacturer or a watch maker. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Rotate the crown at the top of the watch to set the time.
steps.content: Rotate the crown at the top of the watch to set the time. Turn the crown to rotate the hands of the clock until they reach the right time. Turning the crown clockwise or counterclockwise will move the hands in that same direction. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Push the lever back into its original position.
steps.content: Push the lever back into its original position. This will finish setting the clock. Use your finger nail to gently snap it back under the dial of the watch. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Replace the crystal and bezel case if necessary.
steps.content: Replace the crystal and bezel case if necessary. Screw it back on or snap it back into place by pressing down on the bezel or metal rim of the case. The clock should be ready to use. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Wind the clock using the crown if needed.
steps.content: Wind the clock using the crown if needed. If the lever is pushed into its original position, turning the crown will wind the watch. Turn the crown clockwise to wind it. It will stop turning when it is fully wound. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Determine if the key goes in the front or back.
steps.content: Determine if the key goes in the front or back. Most key-set watches have a square peg (known as an arbor) in the center of the dial. If you see a square shape raised up from the arbor, set the watch from the front. Some may be set from the back, however. If you see a hole directly in the center of the back of clock, set the watch from the back. [15] X Research source If there is an off-center hole in the back, it is probably for winding and not setting. Some may have 2 holes: a center hole for setting and an off-center hole for winding.

steps.title: Find the key to the watch.
steps.content: Find the key to the watch. Key-set watches require a key to turn. Do not try winding the clock with your hands, as this could damage the watch. If the key is lost, you can buy pocket watch keys online or from a watchmaker. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Open the glass dial case if the watch has a square arbor.
steps.content: Open the glass dial case if the watch has a square arbor. This case may screw off. If it doesn’t, look for a lip or indentation on the side of the watch. Use a fingernail to pry the lip up, opening the crystal front of the pocket watch. If you can’t find the lip, look on the opposite side of the watch as the hinges. [17] X Research source This case is called the bezel and crystal on most watches. This is the case that protects the hands of the clock. The bezel is the metal rim while the crystal is the glass.

steps.title: Place the open end of the key over the center arbor or in the back hole.
steps.content: Place the open end of the key over the center arbor or in the back hole. One end of the key will have a hole. Place this hole over the center arbor. It should fit snugly over the key. If the watch is set from a hole on the back, insert the key into this hole. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Turn the key to change the time on the watch.
steps.content: Turn the key to change the time on the watch. You can turn the key clockwise or counterclockwise. As you turn it, the hands of the clock will move in that direction. Once you have set the clock to the right time, stop turning. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the key from the clock before closing the case.
steps.content: Remove the key from the clock before closing the case. Do not press down on the crystal, as you could break, damage, or dirty the crystal. Close the case and press down on the outer metal rim. Put the key somewhere safe until you need it again. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Wind the watch using the key in the winding hole.
steps.content: Wind the watch using the key in the winding hole. The winding hole is usually located on the back of the watch. The hole will be closer to the outside edges of the watch than the center. Turn the key clockwise. You should hear a winding noise. The key will not turn when the clock is fully wound. [21] X Research source In some rare cases, a key-set watch may wind counterclockwise. If the key won’t turn clockwise, don’t force it. Try turning it counterclockwise instead.

steps.title: Locate the button near the winding stem.
steps.content: Locate the button near the winding stem. The button will be very small, but it will be raised up above the rest of the case. It is usually located on the top ridge, close to the winding stem and crown. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Hold down on the button with a fingernail or pin.
steps.content: Hold down on the button with a fingernail or pin. You must keep holding this button until you are done setting your watch. Use 1 hand to hold the button steady. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Turn the crown to set the time.
steps.content: Turn the crown to set the time. You can turn the crown clockwise or counterclockwise. Whichever way you turn the crown, the hands will move in that direction. Turn the hands until they display the proper time. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Release the button to wind the clock.
steps.content: Release the button to wind the clock. The clock should now display the right time. If you need to, you can wind the clock by turning the crown clockwise. As long as you are not holding onto the pin button, the clock should wind. [25] X Research source
